awd_titl_txt: CDS&E: Reliable Atomistic Simulation under Uncertainties
awd_abstract_narration:
This research is about how to gain higher confidence and better understanding of atomistic processes via simulation with the lack of perfect knowledge about physical systems, and how to improve the robustness of simulation prediction. The approach of this research will be rigorous and efficient quantification of input uncertainty associated with simulation models and its effects. The investigation will include new mechanisms that perform molecular dynamics simulation with incomplete knowledge of the system's states, kinetic Monte Carlo simulation with imprecise reaction and transition rates, first-principles reliable kinetic Monte Carlo simulation under uncertainties, as well as model calibration and validation with the incorporation of model errors and measurement errors. 

If successful, the benefits of this research will include an efficient computational approach to enable rational design of clean and safe nanoscale products and materials (e.g. drugs, catalysts, fuel cells) in an affordable way to improve people's daily lives, enhanced computational infrastructure across disciplines to facilitate simulation-based scientific discovery and scalable nanomaterials production, publicly available open-source software for research and as an education tool for engineers and scientists, as well as course modules for teachers and 8th grade students on nanoscale engineering.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. A novel kinetic Monte Carlo simulation scheme based on imprecise probability is developed to incorporate model form uncertainty in the simulation. A multiscale model validation scheme based on a generalized interval Bayes’ rule is developed where information fusion is achieved under both aleatory and epistemic uncertainties. A novel molecular dynamics simulation scheme based on Kaucher interval arithmetic is developed to simulate atomistic systems with imprecise interatomic potentials. A Gaussian process modeling method to quantify model-form uncertainty in density functional theory is developed, where stable and transition states of materials can be identified from first-principles simulations along with efficient sensitivity assessment. A distributed Gaussian process modeling approach is developed to significantly improve the scalability and computational efficiency for high-dimensional uncertainty quantification problems, which can scale the dimension from a few to dozens or hundreds. A cross-scale dynamics scheme is developed to propagate uncertainty associated with thermodynamic properties in molecular systems to longer time scales in stochastic dynamics simulation. 

 

Broader Impacts. The developed reliable kinetic Monte Carlo simulation and reliable molecular dynamics simulation packages are available at http://github.com/GeorgiaTechMSSE. They have been applied and demonstrated in material property predictions and manufacturing process simulations with significantly reduced computational cost for sensitivity analysis under uncertainty. Four graduate students and three undergraduate students directly participated in the project and gained STEM and multidisciplinary knowledge. High school math teachers were also involved for summer internship program. The education and dissemination of knowledge also include one edited journal special issue and several symposiums on uncertainty quantification for multiscale simulation. The research resulted in seven journal papers and eight conference publications, including one best poster award, as well as keynote presentation, invited seminars, and two dozen workshop and conference presentations broadly in the societies of materials science, applied mathematics, risk analysis, computational science, engineering design, and manufacturing.


Last Modified: 12/02/2017
Modified by: Yan Wang
